questions.text: Which of the following drugs exacerbates myasthenia and is usually avoided in a patient with myasthenia gravis? Lidocaine Digene Meropenem Phenytoin
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - 1 & 2

questions.text: Dopamine at low doses causes:
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D - Increases renal blood flow.

Dopamine Dose

Receptor Activation

Effects

< 2 µg/kg/min

D1 receptors

Increases renal blood flow; vasodilation in renal and mesenteric vessels

2-10 µg/kg/min

β1 receptors (heart)

Increases heart rate (positive chronotropic) and contractility (positive inotropy)

> 10 µg/kg/min

α1 receptors

Vasoconstriction (increased systemic vascular resistance) and increased blood pressure

questions.text: A child, after disturbing a bee hive, experienced several stings. A few minutes later, the child developed breathing difficulty and hypotension. What is the drug of choice for managing this child?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Adrenaline

Uses of Epinephrine

Condition

Use

Dilution/Concentration

Route of Administration

Anaphylaxis

First-line treatment for severe allergic reactions

1:1000 (1 mg/mL)
  • Intramuscular (IM)

Cardiac arrest

To restore cardiac rhythm and blood pressure

1:10,000 (0.1 mg/mL)
  • Intravenous (IV)
  • Intraosseous (IO)

Asthma

Treatment of acute severe asthma attacks

1:1000 (1 mg/mL)
  • Inhalation via nebulizer
  • Intramuscular (IM)
  • subcutaneous (SC)

Hypotension

To increase blood pressure

1:100,000 (0.01 mg/mL)
  • Intravenous (IV) infusion

Local anesthesia

Enhance duration and intensity of the local anaesthetic effect

1:200,000 to 1:100,000 (0.005 to 0.01 mg/mL)
  • Local injection

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with muscle weakness, blurred vision after exertion, and ptosis, which improves after undergoing the edrophonium test. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer B - Myasthenia grav

questions.text: Which of the options below acts as a selective alpha-1 receptor antagonist in medical practice?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C - Prazosin

Classification of Alpha-blockers based on their receptor binding

Types

Drugs

Non-
competitive + irreversible type

Phenoxybenzamine

 

Competitive + reversible type

Non-selective

 

 

 

Phentolamine

Ergotamine

Ergotoxine

Chlorpromazine

 

 

 

 

 

Alpha 1 selective

Drugs

Location

Effects

Alpha 1 a

Tamsulosin

Silodosin

Internal Urethral Sphincter

Iris

Ejaculation failure/retrograde ejaculation, miosis, increased urine outflow

Alpha 1 b

Alfuzosin

Doxazosin

Prazosin

Terazosin

Vascular Smooth Muscle

Vasodilatation, reflex tachycardia, reduced GFR (thus leading to RAAS activation)

Alpha 2 selective

Yohimbine

Idoxazon

Central Nervous System

Penile erection (used in depression with sexual dysfunction)

Prazosin is a highly selective ɑ1 blocker.

Side effects
  • Postural hypotension (first dose effect) - due to alpha 1b receptor blockade on vascular smooth muscles
  • Retrograde ejaculation: Due to alpha 1a receptors blockade on internal urethral sphincter
  • Floppy iris syndrome: Due to the blockade of the alpha 1a receptor on the iris
  • Reflex tachycardia occurs due to vasodilation.

Uses
  • Hypertension
  • Benign prostatic hyperplasia
  • Raynaud’s disease
  • Scorpion Bite.

questions.text: The dose at which dopamine acts on beta-1 receptors is _________?
questions.explanation:
Different effects of dopamine based on dose

Dose

Effects

<2 mcg/kg/min

Stimulated D1 and D2 receptors, which increased blood flow to the renal and mesenteric vessels

2-5 mcg/kg/min

Dopamine acts on cardiac beta-1 receptors, which increases myocardial contractility. It is also used during cardiogenic shock.

5-15 mcg/kg/min

Dopamine acts on alpha-1 receptors to increase peripheral vascular resistance.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most effective drug in smoking cessation?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - V

 

Mechanism of Action

Effect on Smoking Cessation

First-Line Drugs

Bupropion

Blocks reuptake of dopamine and norepinephrine in the brain

Reduces nicotine withdrawal symptoms and cravings

Nicotine Replacement Therapy (NRT)

Provides controlled nicotine dose (patches, gum, lozenges, inhalers). Never given orally, sublingual due to its fast absorption

Alleviates withdrawal symptoms and cravings, gradually reducing nicotine dependence

Varenicline

Binds to nicotine receptors in the brain, partially stimulating them.

Most effective drug.

Reduces cravings and pleasurable effects of smoking.

Used in tobacco chewing.
S/E: Depression (suicides)

All first-line drugs are C/I in seizures and heart diseases (MI, angina, hypertension)

Second-Line Drugs

Clonidine
 

Alpha-2 adrenergic agonist, reduces sympathetic nervous system activity
  • Alleviates withdrawal symptoms such as anxiety, irritability, and restlessness.
  • Safe in patients with heart disease/seizure.

Nortriptyline

 

Tricyclic antidepressant, affecting norepinephrine and serotonin levels
  • Reduces withdrawal symptoms and cravings

Topiramate

 

Blocks glutamate receptors and facilitates GABA neurotransmission
  • Potentially facilitates smoking cessation

Mecamylamine

Blocks nicotine receptors in the brain
  • Reduces the rewarding effects of nicotine, making smoking less appealing.
  • Used in nicotine poisoning.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can be used to treat open-angle glaucoma in a patient with bronchial asthma?
questions.explanation:
Latanoprost

MOA
  • Alters ciliary muscle tension - improves aqueous humour outflow

Advantages

  • High efficacy
  • Once daily application only
  • No systemic side effects

Disadvantages

  • Expensive

Adverse effects

  • Blurring of vision
  • Iris pigmentation
  • Thickening and darkening of eyelashes
  • Macular edema (in aphakic patients )

Drugs used in the management of glaucoma

Drugs increasing trabecular outflow

  • Miotics
  • Dipivefrine, Epinephrine
  • Bimatoprost
  • Netarsidil

Drugs increasing uveoscleral outflow

  • PGF2α analogue - Latanoprost

Drugs decreasing aqueous humour production

  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors - Acetazolamide

Hyperosmotic agents

  • Mannitol
  • Urea

questions.text: A patient presented with a history of multiple episodes of vomiting. He was given intravenous medication for the same. Later, he developed abnormal movements. Which of the following drugs can be used to treat him?
questions.explanation:
Metoclopramide

MOA
  • Dopamine receptor antagonist; acts centrally as a prokinetic and anti-emetic.

Side effects

  • Extrapyramidal symptoms
    • Acute dystonia - occurs shortly after IV injection
    • Parkinson-like symptoms seen after weeks of therapy
    • Irreversible tardive dyskinesia - occurs with chronic treatment
  • Galactorrhoea
  • Methemoglobinemia

Management of extrapyramidal symptoms

  • Discontinuation of the drug.
  • Benzhexol - centrally acting anticholinergic agents.
  • Restores cholinergic balance in the striatal interneurons.

questions.text: The response on stimulation of the muscarinic receptor is _
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - E

questions.text: Which of the following medications is most commonly used for maintenance therapy in opioid withdrawal?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Buprenorph

questions.text: A patient with diabetes developed postoperative urinary retention. Which of the following drugs can be used for short-term treatment of the condition?
questions.explanation:
Bethanechol

Bethanechol is a cholinergic agonist that stimulates muscarinic receptors, which are found primarily in the urinary and gastrointestinal tracts.

MOA
  • Mimics the effects of acetylcholine, which plays a crucial role in the parasympathetic nervous system, at muscarinic receptors.
  • Upon stimulating muscarinic receptors, it promotes bladder muscle contraction, aiding in urine expulsion and reducing urinary retention.

Clinical Usage
  • Postoperative and Postpartum urinary retention with no actual obstruction.
  • Neurogenic bladder.
  • Symptomatic relief in congenital megacolon.
  • Gastroesophageal reflux

Side Effects
  • Gastrointestinal: Belching, involuntary defecation.
  • Urinary: Involuntary urination.
  • Other: Flushing, sweating, hypotension.

Contraindications
  • Mechanical obstruction of the gastrointestinal or urinary tract.
  • Asthma.
  • Hypotension.

questions.text: A patient was prescribed an antipsychotic drug, following which he developed Parkinsonism. Which of the following drugs can be given?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - Trihexyph

questions.text: Beta-blockers are ideally avoided in which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Diabetes mellitus with hypertension

Uses of beta-blockers

Drug of choice
  • Migraine prophylaxis (Option D)
  • Essential tremors (Option A)
  • Aortic dissection if they also have hypertension

Other Uses
  • Hypertension-second-line drugs
  • Stable angina: Decrease the frequency of attacks and increase exercise tolerance. (Option C)
  • Cardiac arrhythmias: Used in both supraventricular and ventricular arrhythmias.
  • Congestive heart failure: Decreases mortality.
  • Thyrotoxicosis: Propranolol controls the sympathetic symptoms
  • Glaucoma: Timolol and Betaxolol are used.
  • Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (Improves cardiac output).
  • Myocardial infarction (Ml): Secondary prophylaxis of Ml and myocardial salvage during evolution of Ml (decreases mortality).

questions.text: Beta-blockers should be avoided in all except.
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Glaucoma

Explanation:

Types of beta-blocker

Examples

Uses

Non-selective beta-blocker

Propranolol, nadolol
  • Hypertension
  • Angina
  • Arrhythmias
  • Migraine prophylaxis

Beta-1-selective blockers

Metoprolol, Atenolol
  • Hypertension
  • Heart failure
  • Arrhythmias

Beta-1-with Alpha-1 blockade

Carvedilol, Labetalol
  • Hypertension
  • Heart failure
  • Post-MI

Side effects of beta-blocker

Cardiac side effects

  • Precipitation of an acute MI.
  • Sinus bradycardia and heart block. (Option C)
  • Heart failure may exacerbate symptoms in patients with decompensated heart failure or preexisting myocardial dysfunction.

Extracardiac side effects

  • Increased airway resistance; hence, it is contraindicated in patients with asthma due to bronchospasm. (Option A)
  • Exacerbation of peripheral artery disease and worsen claudication and precipitate Raynaud's disease.
  • In Hypoglycemia, Beta-blockers mask the signs seen in a hypoglycemic patient, such as tachycardia.
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Depression, fatigue, and sexual dysfunction such as erectile dysfunction.
  • Weight gain

questions.text: A chronic smoker was taking nicotine therapy and clonidine tablets for smoking de-addiction. He stopped taking clonidine tablets and developed a headache. What is the reason behind this?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C - Rebound h

Rebound Hypertension

Symptoms

A sudden increase in blood pressure, headache, palpitations, sweating, anxiety, dizziness, confusion, chest pain.

Diagnosis

Based on symptoms and blood pressure readings

Treatment

Gradual tapering of the medication, blood pressure monitoring, and use of alternative medications if needed.

Prevention

Avoid abrupt discontinuation of medications and gradual tapering under medical supervision.

questions.text: A patient comes to the casualty with consumption of OPC pesticide. He was started on IV atropine infusion and pralidoxime. After 2 hours, the patient had a sudden rise in temperature. What is the cause of the fever?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - Atropine

questions.text: A young male patient presents with ptosis and muscle weakness, which reportedly worsens in the evening and improves in the morning. This is relieved by neostigmine. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Myasthenia gravis:

Pathophysiology

Autoimmune disease is caused by antibodies targeting acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction.

Disruption in neuromuscular transmission occurs through:

  • Blockage of acetylcholine receptors.
  • Complement-mediated inflammation leads to:
    • Reduced receptor count.
    • Damage to the end plate.

Clinical features
  • Fatigable muscle weakness: Muscle strength decreases with continued use, especially:
    • Later in the day
    • After exercise
  • No sensory or CNS involvement, distinguishing it from other neurological disorders.

Common Initial Symptoms:

  • Ptosis (drooping eyelid)
  • Diplopia (double vision)
  • Weakness can spread to:
    • Chewing, swallowing, and speaking muscles
    • Limb muscles

Diagnosis

Tensilon (edrophonium) Test

  • This involves the injection of Edrophonium (a short-acting anticholinesterase agent) into individuals with a deficiency of acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction.
  • Steps: 2 mg i.v. Edrophonium → Observe for any adverse reactions → If no adverse reactions occur after 30–60 seconds, the remaining 8 mg is injected.
  • If muscle strength improves after the administration of edrophonium, it indicates the presence of Myasthenia Gravis.

Management

Anticholinesterase agents (inhibit the breakdown of ACh by acetylcholinesterase and increase presynaptic levels of ACh, allowing for muscle contraction).

  • Pyridostigmine (drug of choice)
  • Neostigmine
  • Ambenonium

questions.text: Unknown fruit consumption by a child, odd behaviour, fever and low urine output. Causative fruit and treatment is:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer B) Datura - Physostig

questions.text: What treatment can be administered to a patient brought to the emergency department with symptoms of diarrhea, sweating, excessive lacrimation, salivation, a garlicky odor, a pulse rate of 55/min, and a plasma cholinesterase level of 50 U/mL?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Atropine

Organophosphate poisoning

Common exposures
  • Pesticide: Farmer/field worker, pediatric ingestion, suicide attempt
  • Nerve agent: Multiple patients presenting with similar symptoms

Manifestations

 

Muscarinic (DUMBBELSS) :

  • D-Diarrhea
  • U-Urination
  • M-Miosis
  • B-Bronchospasms, bronchorrhea, bradycardia
  • E-Excitation, Emesis
  • L-Lacrimation
  • S-Salivation, sweating

Nicotinic:

  • Muscle weakness, paralysis, fasciculations.

Management
  • Decontamination
  • Atropine reverses muscarinic symptoms
  • Pralidoxime reverses nicotinic and muscarinic symptoms (reactivates cholinesterase)

questions.text: A man was brought to the emergency room after poisoning with an unknown substance. Muscarinic poisoning was suspected, and he was treated for the same. What is the possible presenting feature that led to the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Muscarinic poisoning

Laboratory Diagnosis
  • RBC/True Cholinesterase (specific)
  • Plasma/Pseudocholinesterase (Most common)
    • Falls rapidly with organophosphorus poisoning
    • Inexpensive, sensitive)
  • Atropine test: If 2 mg of Atropine relieves symptoms, it confirms OP poisoning
  • P-nitro phenol test for confirmation.

Management
  • Resuscitative measures (Airway-Breathing-Circulation)
  • Decontamination
  • Gastric lavage with 1:5000 KMnO4
  • Activated charcoal
  • Atropine sulfate (2-4 mg IV every 10-15 minutes until atropinization)
  • Signs of atropinization: Heart rate>80 beats/min, pupils no longer pinpoint, clear chest on auscultation with no wheeze, systolic BP>80mmHg, Dry axillae
  • Oximes (Pralidoxime) to decrease muscarinic and CNS symptoms
    • removes phosphate group
    • reduces atropine requirement

Cause of Death

Respiratory Muscle Paralysis (RMP)

questions.text: A patient with erectile dysfunction is given sildenafil. The penile erectile function is found to be improved after the therapy. Which of the following mediates the action of sildenafil ?
questions.explanation:
Sildenafil

↓

Inhibits phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE-5) enzyme

↓

Prevents cGMP degradation

↓

Increases cytosolic cGMP levels

↓

Prolongs activation of GMP-dependent protein kinase

↓

Inhibits myosin light chain kinase dephosphorylation

↓

Smooth muscle relaxation in the corpus cavernosum

↓

Increased blood flow

↓

Sustained penile erection

questions.text: Which of the following cannot be used to decrease intraocular pressure in glaucoma ?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Dexameth

Medication

Mechanism of Action

Prostaglandin analogs

Increase uveoscleral outflow of aqueous humor

Beta blockers

Decrease production of aqueous humor

Alpha-adrenergic agonists

Decrease production and increase outflow of aqueous humor

Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors

Decrease production of aqueous humor

Miotic agents

Increase outflow of aqueous humor

Osmotic agents

Reduce intraocular pressure by osmotic effect

questions.text: Pilocarpine produces:
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Activ

questions.text: A 5-year-old male child is brought to the ophthalmology clinic by his mother with complaints of blurring of vision for one week. The patient further explains that he only has blurring of the far vision and has no problem in his near vision. The patient gives a history of no other abnormalities. For a detailed examination of the eye, the doctor uses a short-acting topical medication which also has a cycloplegic effect. Which of the following drug was used by the doctor in this case?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - T

Cycloplegic Drug

Duration of Action

Tropicamide

Short-acting (3-6 hours)

Cyclopentolate

Intermediate-acting (6-24 hours)

Homatropine

Intermediate-acting (6-24 hours)

Atropine

Long-acting (up to 7 days)

Scopolamine

Long-acting (up to 7 days)

questions.text: Intravenous mannitol is used in ____________?
questions.explanation: Correct Option D - Glau

questions.text: What is the drug used to differentiate myasthenia gravis from cholinergic crisis ?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Edrophoniu

Aspect

Myasthenia Gravis (MG)

Cholinergic Crisis

Edrophonium Test

Definition

Autoimmune disorder affecting neuromuscular junction

Excessive stimulation of cholinergic receptors

Diagnostic test to differentiate MG from cholinergic crisis

Symptoms

Muscle weakness, fatigue

Profound muscle weakness, respiratory distress

Temporary improvement of muscle strength in MG, worsening of symptoms in cholinergic crisis

Cause

Antibodies attacking acetylcholine receptors

Excessive acetylcholine due to overstimulation
  • In MG: Temporary increase in acetylcholine concentration at neuromuscular junction
  • In Cholinergic Crisis: Worsening of symptoms due to increased acetylcholine levels

Response to Edrophonium

Temporary improvement in muscle strength

Worsening of symptoms

Positive response in MG, Negative/worsening response in cholinergic crisis

Mechanism

 

Acetylcholinesterase inhibitor

 

Acetylcholine receptor overstimulation

 
  • In MG: Inhibits acetylcholinesterase, increasing acetylcholine availability
  • In Cholinergic Crisis: Further increases acetylcholine levels, worsening symptoms

questions.text: What dose of epinephrine is used anaphylactic shock ?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - 1:1000 I.M. - 0.5

Adrenaline Concentration

Common Uses

1:1,000 (1 mg/mL)

  • Treatment of severe allergic reactions, such as anaphylaxis

  • Cardiac arrest resuscitation

  • Management of bronchospasm in asthma and other respiratory conditions

  • Hemostasis in minor surgical procedures

1:10,000 (0.1 mg/mL)

  • Cardiac arrest resuscitation

  • Severe bradycardia or heart block

  • Management of life-threatening arrhythmias

  • Hypotension during anesthesia or shock

Intranasal formulations

  • Treatment of nasal congestion

  • Epistaxis (nosebleeds) control

Inhalation formulations

  • Management of acute asthma attacks

  • Reversal of bronchospasm due to respiratory conditions

  • Respiratory support in acute respiratory distress or failure

Topical formulations

  • Hemostasis in minor cuts, wounds, or mucosal bleeding

  • Local vasoconstriction during procedures (e.g., to control bleeding)

Eye drop formulations

  • Mydriasis (pupil dilation) for ophthalmic examinations

  • Relief of ocular redness and itching due to allergies or inflammation

questions.text: A patient came to the causality with acute bronchial asthma after treatment for glaucoma . Which of the following is a most probable causative agent?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - T

Class of Drug

Examples

Adverse Effects

Prostaglandin analogs

Latanoprost, Bimatoprost, Travoprost, Tafluprost

Conjunctival hyperemia, ocular surface disease, iris pigmentation, eyelash growth, uveitis, macular edema

Beta-blockers

Timolol, Betaxolol, Levobunolol, Carteolol, Metipranolol

Bronchospasm, bradycardia, hypotension, fatigue, depression, impotence

Alpha-2 agonists

Brimonidine

Ocular allergy, dry mouth, fatigue, headache, hypotension, bradycardia, dizziness

Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors

Dorzolamide, Brinzolamide

Bitter taste, ocular stinging, blurred vision, dry mouth, fatigue, depression, electrolyte disturbances

Rho kinase inhibitors

Netarsudil

Ocular hyperemia, conjunctival hemorrhage, eyelash growth

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the treatment of a farmer presenting with symptoms of diarrhea, sweating, excessive tearing, and salivation in the emergency department is not accurate?

options.label: B
options.text: Atropine is used as an antidote for OP poisoning

options.label: C
options.text: Pralidoxime has a role in reversing the enzyme in carbamate poisoning

options.label: D
options.text: Succinylcholine use is avoided in rapid sequence intubation

questions.correct_answer: C. Pralidoxime has a role in reversing the enzyme in carbamate poisoning
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Pralidoxime has a role in reversing the enzyme in carbamate poisoning

Drug

Mechanism of Action

Indication

Adverse Effects

Atropine

The competitive antagonist of acetylcholine at muscarinic receptors

Symptomatic relief of muscarinic symptoms (e.g., bradycardia, bronchoconstriction, sweating, salivation)

Tachycardia, dry mouth, mydriasis, urinary retention

Pralidoxime

Reactivates acetylcholinesterase by removing the OP molecule from the enzyme

Reversal of neuromuscular blockade and improvement of muscle strength; may improve respiratory function and reduce the need for mechanical ventilation.

Hypertension, tachycardia, blurred vision, headache

Diazepam

Enhances the activity of GABA, an inhibitory neurotransmitter in the brain

Sedation, anticonvulsant activity, and relief of anxiety and agitation

Drowsiness, respiratory depression, hypotension

Midazolam

Enhances the activity of GABA, an inhibitory neurotransmitter in the brain

Sedation, anticonvulsant activity, and relief of anxiety and agitation

Drowsiness, respiratory depression, hypotension
